title: A Phase 1/2, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of AstroStem, Autologous Adipose Tissue Derived Mesenchymal Stem Cells, in Patients With Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group comparison study in subjects with Alzheimer's Disease. Following first screening period, subjects will be randomly assigned into one of the following arms: AstroStem and placebo control in a 1:1 ratio. AstroStem or placebo control will be administered via I.V. at Week 0. This procedure will be repeated 9 times at 2-week interval. Subjects will be scheduled for two follow-up visits at Weeks 30 and 52 to evaluate primary and secondary outcome endpoints.

outcomeMeasures.title: Treatment Related Adverse Events
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of subjects with treatment related adverse events as assessed by analysis of adverse events including symptoms, and abnormal findings on physical examination, vital signs, ECG, and standard laboratory examination results

groups.title: AstroStem

outcomeMeasures.title: ADAS-Cog (Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-cognitive Subscale)
outcomeMeasures.description: Change of ADAS-Cog (Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-cognitive subscale) from Baseline at Week 30 Score range: 0-70 A score of 70 represents the most severe impairment and 0 represents the least impairment
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription:
3 of the 11 astrostem groups were dropped out and 1 was violated protocol.

1 of the 10 Placebo-control groups was dropped out and 2 were violated protocol.

outcomeMeasures.description: Change of MMSE from baseline at Week 30 Score range: 0-30 A score of 20 to 24 suggests mild dementia, 13 to 20 suggests moderate dementia, and less than 12 indicates severe dementia.

drug: AstroStem (autologous adipose tissue-derived mesenchymal stem cells; AdMSCs)
explanation_target: Reason: The investigational product AstroStem is an autologous cell therapy composed of adipose‑derived mesenchymal stem cells (AdMSCs), i.e., a biological product rather than a small molecule or device. The trial description and registry list AstroStem explicitly as autologous adipose tissue‑derived mesenchymal stem cells. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details — randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study of AstroStem administered intravenously in repeated infusions (multiple IV doses over weeks) vs placebo (saline + auto‑serum). Sponsor listed as Nature Cell Co. Ltd.; primary/secondary outcomes include cognitive scales (ADAS‑Cog, CDR‑SB) and amyloid PET SUVR in related entries. These registry entries confirm the product identity and dosing approach. citeturn0search0turn0search2

Reflect: Classification rationale — because AstroStem is a cell‑based biological therapy (autologous MSCs) intended to treat Alzheimer’s disease (with outcomes measuring cognitive change and biomarkers), it fits the 'disease‑targeted biologic' category (biologic intervention aimed at modifying disease processes / neurorepair or immunomodulation), not a small molecule, symptomatic cognitive enhancer only, or a neuropsychiatric‑symptom trial. The mechanism in the registry is not deeply detailed, but mesenchymal stem cell therapies are biologics and are typically intended to modify disease biology; therefore the classification as 'disease‑targeted biologic' is appropriate. citeturn0search7turn0search0

Web search sources used: NCT registry / trial records showing AstroStem = autologous adipose‑derived mesenchymal stem cells and study details (NCT03117738; NCT04482413). citeturn0search0turn0search1

Notes / ambiguity: The trial record does not state a specific molecular target (e.g., amyloid or tau ligand) for the MSCs; cell therapies may act via multiple mechanisms (neurotrophic support, immunomodulation, neurorepair) rather than a single defined protein target. If you want, I can pull the full trial entry(s) or published results for more mechanistic detail. citeturn0search7turn0search3
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational product AstroStem is an autologous adipose‑derived mesenchymal stem cell (AdMSC) therapy — a cell‑based biologic that is not directed at a single molecular species (e.g., amyloid or tau) but is reported to act via pleiotropic mechanisms (neurotrophic support, immunomodulation, repair). citeturn0search2turn0search1turn0search0

Act: Key extracted trial details — a Phase 1/2 randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study of AstroStem administered intravenously in repeated infusions (multiple IV doses over weeks) vs placebo; small completed cohort (n≈21) in the registered study. The registry and summaries identify the product explicitly as autologous adipose‑derived mesenchymal stem cells. citeturn0search2turn0search3turn0search1

Reflect: CADRO mapping rationale — because the intervention is a cell therapy with multiple putative mechanisms (neurogenesis/neurorepair, immunomodulation/anti‑inflammation, neuroprotection) rather than a single defined molecular target, the most specific CADRO assignment is R) Multi‑target. If you prefer a more granular mapping, MSC effects overlap CADRO categories E (Neurogenesis), F (Inflammation), and M (Synaptic plasticity/Neuroprotection), but none alone captures the multi‑mechanistic nature. citeturn0search1

Web search sources (supporting statements above): PR Newswire / Nature Cell announcement of AstroStem trials; Alzforum summary of autologous adipose‑derived stem cell programs and mechanisms; clinical trial registry snapshots for NCT03117738 (AstroStem Phase 1/2). citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search2turn0search3
